description: Two-person reasoning evaluation where a premise is given in a box and two characters make logical statements. Determine whose reasoning is correct.

concepts.name: Evaluating Two Competing Claims
concepts.description: Given a premise, determine which of two people's conclusions correctly follows from the given information
common_misconceptions: Agreeing with the more confident-sounding person
Not carefully checking each claim against the premise
Missing subtle differences in the claims
question_patterns: [Premise in box]. Person A says [claim]. Person B says [claim]. Who is correct?
Based on the information given, whose reasoning is valid?
example_stems: All cats have tails. Fluffy is a cat. Amy says Fluffy has a tail. Ben says all animals with tails are cats. Who is correct?
The store closes at 5pm. It is 4:30pm. Maya says the store is open. Noah says we have 30 minutes. Who is right?

concepts.name: Both Conclusions Correct
concepts.description: Recognizing when both people's conclusions validly follow from the premise
common_misconceptions: Thinking only one person can be right
Not considering that both might follow logically
Looking for conflict where none exists
question_patterns: Based on the premise, which of the following is true about the two claims?
Are both conclusions valid? Why or why not?
example_stems: All squares are rectangles. Kim says squares have 4 right angles. Lee says squares have 4 sides. Who is correct?
The number is even. Pat says it's divisible by 2. Sam says it's not odd. Whose reasoning is valid?

concepts.name: Neither Conclusion Correct
concepts.description: Recognizing when both people make errors in their reasoning from the premise
common_misconceptions: Feeling forced to choose one person
Not noticing flaws in both arguments
Assuming at least one must be right
question_patterns: Based on the premise, which statement is true?
Who reasons correctly from the given information?
example_stems: Some birds can fly. Robin says all birds fly. Jordan says no birds swim. Who is correct?
The box is heavy. Alex says it contains books. Morgan says it's too heavy to lift. Who is right?

concepts.name: Reasoning with Partial Information
concepts.description: Drawing valid conclusions when the premise doesn't tell us everything
common_misconceptions: Assuming more than the premise states
Concluding something is false just because it's not stated
question_patterns: What can definitely be concluded from the information given?
example_stems: Some students play sports. Emma says all students play sports. Oliver says some students don't play sports. Who is correct?
The train is delayed. Lily says it will arrive late. Jake says it won't arrive at all. Who reasons correctly?

concepts.name: Reasoning with Quantifiers
concepts.description: Understanding the logical implications of 'all', 'some', 'none', and 'not all'
common_misconceptions: Assuming 'some' means 'exactly some but not all'
question_patterns: Given that [quantified statement], what must be true?
If some X are Y, what follows about X and Y?
example_stems: Not all fruits are sweet. Chloe says some fruits are not sweet. Dylan says no fruits are sweet. Who is correct?
All rectangles have 4 sides. Grace says all shapes with 4 sides are rectangles. Henry says rectangles are shapes. Who is right?
